Each year, our 6th graders have a unit in art class on colored pencil portraits. In recent years, we added to this lesson by teaming with The Memory Project, an organization whose mission is to “invite young artists around the world to create portraits as special gifts for children facing challenges.”

Last year, our students were given Syria. This year, our students each received a photo of a child living in a former Soviet Union country. They will use that to create a pencil portrait that will go back to that child, and will also learn about the lives and culture of these children.

Here are some of the students with their initial work...stay tuned for the finished products!

One of the advantages at The Birches Academy is that we have the flexibility to meet students where they are at. We have structured our approach to math around this mission.

We hold our K-5 math classes at the same time of day so that students can move up to the right level for them. In our middle school, they work up through Algebra 1 in 90 minute blocks to allow for deeper learning – and younger students who are working ahead of grade level can join the middle school lessons as well.

One of the unique aspects of The Birches Academy is how we organize our classes. We employ both single-grade and mixed-grade classes. We believe this is the best of both worlds!

In Kindergarten, 3rd and 6th grades, our classes are joined. This not only creates class bonding, but allows for a strong focus on 3 key areas: in Kindergarten, school readiness; in 3rd grade, the shift from learning to read to reading to learn; in 6th grade, executive functioning skills. Then in grades 1/2, 4/5 and 7/8 our students mix together where they loop with teachers who get to know them better and where they can learn with students from a range of learning abilities and strengths.

For the past several years, we've observed SOCKTOBER at The Birches Academy. What does this mean? During the month of October, students collect new socks for men and women who are helped by Blanket Me, a North Andover-based hands-on mission that cares for the homeless.

Today at Forest Forum, our students heard from Sam Salib, a representative from Blanket Me. Sam talked to the kids about empathy and how a pair of socks is a way to build a relationship with the homeless.

This drive is spearheaded by our Sequoia House. Each of the other Houses of The Birches Academy will earn points for their team by bringing in socks throughout the month.

Donations from the public are more than welcome! Drop off is at our school during normal business hours.

Who wants to play some BINGO for a cause?

TONIGHT! A-Brews in Dracut hosts a weekly game of BINGO where the proceeds benefit a local organization and the prizes are meat from Brown and Budnick's Meats in the same Bridgewood Plaza where they're located. This week, The Birches Academy is the beneficiary!

How does it work? You purchase a set of 3 cards and play up to 6 rounds. The DJ has a deck of playing cards and pulls one card out at a time. If you make a BINGO on all three cards, you win that round!

A-Brews has a full bar and food menu. Food & drinks can be paid with credit cards, but BINGO cards are cash only. (There is an ATM on site.)

We hope you'll come down tonight from 6:30-8:30pm for fun and community building. All are welcome!
